definitions.example: Even a minor change can set up new bugs.
I've got to set up that tasty rabbit.

definitions.definition: To arrange for an outcome; to tamper or rig.

definitions.example: Give the cement 24 hours to set up before walking on it.

definitions.definition: Level to rise in one part of a body of water, especially a shallow one, because of a storm surge caused by persistent wind.
definitions.example: The level set up at the south end of the lake after a day of north winds.

definitions.definition: To provide the money or other support that someone needs for an important task or activity.
definitions.example: A good breakfast really sets you up for the day.

definitions.definition: To establish someone in a business or position.
definitions.example: After he left college, his father set him up in the family business.

definitions.definition: To trick someone in order to make them do something.
definitions.example: They claimed that they weren't selling drugs, but that they'd been set up by the police.

definitions.definition: To make (someone) proud or conceited (often in passive).
To matchmake; to arrange a date between two people.
To begin business or a scheme of life.
definitions.example: to set up in trade; to set up for oneself

definitions.definition: To profess openly; to make pretensions.
To found; to start (a business, scheme)
In a position to function; ready.
definitions.example: Now that I'm set up, this will take moments!
